title: Establishes the independent office of the child advocate; repealer
summary: Establishes the independent office of child advocate to ensure the protection and promotion of legal rights for youth in juvenile justice facilities; repeals certain provisions relating to the office of the ombudsman.

       Introduced by M. of A. CLARK, SCARBOROUGH, TITUS, PAULIN, JACOBS, HEAST-
         IE,  BENEDETTO,  PEOPLES-STOKES, N. RIVERA, COLTON, CANESTRARI, GALEF,
         PHEFFER, PERRY, MAYERSOHN, BOYLAND, BUTLER, ROBINSON, ARROYO,  JAFFEE,

         A. CAHILL, CALHOUN, CAMARA, CROUCH, FARRELL, FINCH, GANTT,  GOTTFRIED,
         HIKIND,  LATIMER, LIFTON, LUPARDO, McENENY, McKEVITT, MENG, J. MILLER,

       AN ACT to amend the executive law, in relation to the  establishment  of
         the  independent  office  of the child advocate; and repealing certain
         provisions of such law relating to the office of the ombudsman

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1. Subtitle B of title 3 of article 19-G of the executive law
    2  is REPEALED.
    3    S 2. The executive law is amended by adding a new article 19-I to read
    4  as follows:
    5                                ARTICLE 19-I
    6                  INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE
    7  SECTION 533. INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE; CREATION.
    8          534. DEFINITIONS.
    9          535. THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   10          536. DUTIES OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   11          537. POWERS OF THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   12          538. DUTY TO MAINTAIN CONFIDENTIALITY.
   13          539. ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS.
   14    S 533. INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE;  CREATION.  THERE  IS
   15  HEREBY CREATED IN THE EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, AN INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE
   16  CHILD ADVOCATE, WHICH SHALL:

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD01331-01-1

       A. 644                              2

    1    1.  EXAMINE,  EVALUATE  AND REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLATURE
    2  ON:
    3    (A) PARTICULAR AND SYSTEMIC ISSUES IN PUBLICLY FUNDED JUVENILE JUSTICE
    4  PROGRAMS OVERSEEN BY THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES; AND
    5    (B) MULTI-SYSTEMIC ISSUES THAT CHILDREN IN THE JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM
    6  EXPERIENCE IN ACCESSING NEEDED SERVICES ACROSS SYSTEMS; AND
    7    2.  ADVOCATE  FOR,  AND  REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLATURE ON
    8  SUGGESTED STATUTORY, REGULATORY OR POLICY  CHANGES  AIMED  AT  IMPROVING
    9  OUTCOMES  AND  SERVICES  FOR CHILDREN IN THE JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM AND
   10  THEIR FAMILIES IN NEW YORK STATE.
   11    S 534. DEFINITIONS. AS USED IN THIS ARTICLE:
   12    1. "CHILD" OR "CHILDREN" MEANS:
   13    (A) A PERSON, OR PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF EIGHTEEN; OR
   14    (B) A PERSON OR PERSONS UNDER THE  AGE  OF  TWENTY-ONE  WHO  HAS  BEEN
   15  PLACED INTO A JUVENILE JUSTICE FACILITY IN THE CARE, CUSTODY, OR GUARDI-
   16  ANSHIP  OF  THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES OR A LOCAL SOCIAL
   17  SERVICES DISTRICT PURSUANT TO ARTICLE THREE OF THE FAMILY COURT ACT.
   18    2. "CHILD ADVOCATE" MEANS THE PERSON APPOINTED PURSUANT TO SUBDIVISION
   19  ONE OF SECTION FIVE HUNDRED THIRTY-FIVE OF THIS ARTICLE  TO  DIRECT  AND
   20  OVERSEE THE ACTIVITIES OF THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   21    S  535. THE CHILD ADVOCATE. 1. THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL BE AN INDIVID-
   22  UAL WITH AT LEAST FIVE YEARS EXPERIENCE IN THE GENERAL SUBJECT  AREA  OF
   23  EITHER  CHILD  WELFARE, JUVENILE JUSTICE OR CHILDHOOD BEHAVIORAL HEALTH,
   24  WHO SHALL BE APPOINTED BY THE GOVERNOR UPON THE ADVICE  AND  CONSENT  OF
   25  THE  SENATE  FOR A TERM OF FIVE YEARS. THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL CONTINUE
   26  TO HOLD SUCH POSITION UNTIL HIS OR HER SUCCESSOR IS APPOINTED,  BUT  MAY
   27  BE REMOVED FROM HIS OR HER POSITION IF THE GOVERNOR SHALL DETERMINE THAT
   28  SUCH  CHILD  ADVOCATE  HAS  ABUSED  HIS OR HER RIGHTS, POWERS, OR DUTIES
   29  ESTABLISHED PURSUANT TO THIS ARTICLE OR THAT HE  OR  SHE  HAS  WILLFULLY
   30  FAILED TO CARRY OUT THE DUTIES REQUIRED BY THIS ARTICLE. THE CHILD ADVO-
   31  CATE SHALL REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR, WHO SHALL FIX THE COMPENSATION OF THE
   32  CHILD ADVOCATE WITHIN AMOUNTS APPROPRIATED THEREFOR.
   33    2.  THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE  MAY HIRE OR APPOINT PERSONS AS MAY BE DEEMED
   34  NECESSARY TO CARRY OUT THE DUTIES OF THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD
   35  ADVOCATE. THE DUTIES OF PERSONS EMPLOYED OR APPOINTED BY THE CHILD ADVO-
   36  CATE SHALL BE PERFORMED UNDER THE ADVICE AND SUPERVISION  OF  THE  CHILD
   37  ADVOCATE. PERSONS EMPLOYED OR APPOINTED BY THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE
   38  CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL BE INDIVIDUALS WITH EXPERTISE IN THE AREAS OF CHILD
   39  WELFARE,  JUVENILE  JUSTICE,  CHILDHOOD  BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, FOSTER CARE,
   40  PREVENTIVE SERVICES, OR CHILD CARE, AS EVIDENCED  BY  EXPERTISE  IN  THE
   41  FIELD,  PRACTICE,  ADVOCACY  OR  BY  ACADEMIC  BACKGROUND, THE LEVEL AND
   42  SUFFICIENCY OF WHICH SHALL BE DETERMINED  BY  THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE.  THE
   43  CHILD  ADVOCATE  SHALL  FIX  THE  COMPENSATION  OF  PERSONS  EMPLOYED OR
   44  APPOINTED BY THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE WITHIN AMOUNTS
   45  APPROPRIATED THEREFOR.
   46    S 536. DUTIES OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE. 1. THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL:
   47    (A) EXAMINE, EVALUATE, INVESTIGATE AND REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND  THE
   48  LEGISLATURE  ON  PARTICULAR AND SYSTEMIC ISSUES IN PUBLICLY FUNDED JUVE-
   49  NILE JUSTICE PROGRAMS OVERSEEN BY THE  OFFICE  OF  CHILDREN  AND  FAMILY
   50  SERVICES AND LOCAL SOCIAL SERVICES DISTRICTS; AND
   51    (B)  EXAMINE, EVALUATE, INVESTIGATE AND REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE
   52  LEGISLATURE ON MULTI-SYSTEMIC  ISSUES  THAT  CHILDREN  IN  THE  JUVENILE
   53  JUSTICE  SYSTEM  EXPERIENCE IN ACCESSING NEEDED SERVICES ACROSS SYSTEMS;
   54  AND
   55    (C) MONITOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE POLICIES, REGULATIONS AND  STAT-
   56  UTES  OF  STATE  AGENCIES WHICH MAY BE APPLICABLE TO THE LEGAL RIGHTS OF

       A. 644                              3

    1  CHILDREN IN JUVENILE JUSTICE FACILITIES OVERSEEN BY THE OFFICE OF  CHIL-
    2  DREN  AND  FAMILY  SERVICES  OR A LOCAL SOCIAL SERVICES DISTRICT, OR THE
    3  FAMILY OF SUCH CHILDREN; AND
    4    (D)  MONITOR  THE IMPLEMENTATION OF POLICIES, REGULATIONS AND STATUTES
    5  WHICH MAY HAVE AN IMPACT ON PUBLICLY FUNDED  JUVENILE  JUSTICE  PROGRAMS
    6  OVERSEEN BY THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES; AND
    7    (E)  RECOMMEND  CHANGES  IN  STATE  POLICIES, STATUTES AND REGULATIONS
    8  CONCERNING CHILDREN IN THE JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM AND THE  FAMILIES  OF
    9  SUCH CHILDREN; AND
   10    (F)  RECOMMEND  CHANGES  IN  STATE POLICIES, STATUTES, AND REGULATIONS
   11  CONCERNING PUBLICLY FUNDED JUVENILE JUSTICE PROGRAMS THAT SERVICE  CHIL-
   12  DREN  AND  FAMILIES,  ADMINISTERED  BY THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY
   13  SERVICES OR LOCAL SOCIAL SERVICES DISTRICTS; AND
   14    (G) TAKE APPROPRIATE ACTIONS AIMED AT PROMOTION OF THE RIGHTS, SAFETY,
   15  WELL-BEING, AND BEST INTERESTS OF CHILDREN IN NEW YORK STATE, INCLUDING,
   16  BUT NOT LIMITED TO, UNDERTAKING LEGISLATIVE ADVOCACY, CONDUCTING  PUBLIC
   17  HEARINGS AND MAKING PROPOSALS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE OR SYSTEMIC REFORM; AND
   18    (H)  PROVIDE ADMINISTRATIVE SUPERVISION AND OVERSIGHT TO THE INDEPEND-
   19  ENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE AND DEVOTE FULL-TIME TO THE  DUTIES  OF
   20  HIS OR HER OFFICE; AND
   21    (I)  CONDUCT PERIODIC INSPECTIONS, EVALUATIONS OR REVIEWS OF ANY JUVE-
   22  NILE JUSTICE FACILITY OPERATED BY THE  OFFICE  OF  CHILDREN  AND  FAMILY
   23  SERVICES  AT  ANY  TIME,  WITH OR WITHOUT PRIOR NOTICE. JUVENILE JUSTICE
   24  FACILITY DIRECTORS AND STAFF SHALL COOPERATE WITH SUCH INSPECTION, EVAL-
   25  UATION OR REVIEW. AN ADVOCATE SHALL HAVE THE RIGHT TO INSPECT THE  JUVE-
   26  NILE JUSTICE FACILITY, VISIT ALL AREAS AND OBSERVE ALL PARTS AND ASPECTS
   27  OF SUCH FACILITY PROGRAM; AND
   28    (J) REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLATURE AS NEEDED, BUT NOT LESS
   29  THAN  TWICE PER YEAR. SUCH REPORT SHALL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC,
   30  UNLESS SUCH MATERIALS ARE CONFIDENTIAL PURSUANT TO  STATUTE,  AND  SHALL
   31  INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:
   32    (A)  INFORMATION  CONCERNING  THE  NUMBER AND TYPES OF REVIEWS, EVALU-
   33  ATIONS AND INVESTIGATIONS CONDUCTED BY THE  INDEPENDENT  OFFICE  OF  THE
   34  CHILD ADVOCATE; AND
   35    (B) ANY RECOMMENDATIONS BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE FOR LEGISLATIVE, REGULA-
   36  TORY, OR PUBLIC POLICY CHANGES.
   37    2.  IF  AFTER EXAMINATION PURSUANT TO SUBDIVISION ONE OF THIS SECTION,
   38  THE CHILD ADVOCATE IDENTIFIES A SYSTEMIC PROBLEM  IN  HOW  SERVICES  ARE
   39  PROVIDED TO CHILDREN IN THE CARE, CUSTODY, OR GUARDIANSHIP OF THE OFFICE
   40  OF  CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES OR A LOCAL SOCIAL SERVICES DISTRICT, BY
   41  THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES, OR A LOCAL  SOCIAL  SERVICES
   42  DISTRICT,  OR  ANY  PUBLIC  OR  PRIVATE  ENTITY WHICH CONTRACTS WITH THE
   43  OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND  FAMILY  SERVICES  OR  A  LOCAL  SOCIAL  SERVICES
   44  DISTRICT  TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO SUCH CHILDREN, THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL
   45  PROVIDE SUCH OFFICE, DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY A WRITTEN REPORT OUTLIN-
   46  ING THE FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   47    (A) AN OFFICE, DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY NAMED IN  A  REPORT  BY  THE
   48  CHILD ADVOCATE AS DESCRIBED IN THIS SUBDIVISION SHALL HAVE THE OPTION TO
   49  RESPOND  IN  WRITING  TO THE CHILD ADVOCATE'S FINDINGS, PROVIDED HOWEVER
   50  THAT SUCH WRITTEN RESPONSE MUST BE ISSUED WITHIN  NINETY  DAYS  OF  SUCH
   51  OFFICE, DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY'S RECEIPT OF THE APPLICABLE REPORT BY
   52  THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   53    (B) WITHIN THIRTY DAYS AFTER THE RECEIPT OF A RESPONSE FROM AN OFFICE,
   54  DISTRICT,  AGENCY  OR ENTITY AS DESCRIBED IN THIS SUBDIVISION, THE CHILD
   55  ADVOCATE SHALL ISSUE SUCH RESPONSE, AND THE REPORT ISSUED BY  THE  CHILD

       A. 644                              4

    1  ADVOCATE  PURSUANT TO THIS SUBDIVISION, TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLA-
    2  TURE.
    3    (C)  IF  A RESPONSE OR A WRITTEN REQUEST FOR AN ADDITIONAL THIRTY DAYS
    4  WITH AN EXPLANATION IS NOT RECEIVED BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE WITHIN  NINETY
    5  DAYS  FROM  THE  DATE  THAT  THE CHILD ADVOCATE SENT SUCH REPORT TO SUCH
    6  OFFICE, DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY, THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE  SHALL  PROVIDE
    7  SUCH  REPORT  TO  THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLATURE WITH A NOTICE STATING
    8  THAT SUCH OFFICE, DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY FAILED TO  ISSUE  A  TIMELY
    9  WRITTEN RESPONSE TO THE REPORT BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   10    S  537.  POWERS  OF  THE  INDEPENDENT  OFFICE  OF  THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   11  NOTWITHSTANDING ANY PROVISION OF LAW OR REGULATION TO THE CONTRARY,  THE
   12  INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL HAVE ACCESS TO, INCLUDING
   13  THE  RIGHT  TO  INSPECT AND COPY, ANY RECORDS NECESSARY TO CARRY OUT ITS
   14  RIGHTS, POWERS AND DUTIES PURSUANT TO THIS ARTICLE,  INCLUDING  BUT  NOT
   15  LIMITED  TO,  PERSONNEL  RECORDS  THAT BEAR ON ANY ISSUE BEING REVIEWED,
   16  EVALUATED, OR INVESTIGATED AND RECORDS OF CHILDREN  UNDER  CARE  OF  THE
   17  JUVENILE  JUSTICE  SYSTEM  THAT BEAR ON ANY ISSUE BEING REVIEWED, EVALU-
   18  ATED, OR INVESTIGATED. THE INDEPENDENT  OFFICE  OF  THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE
   19  SHALL  ALSO HAVE THE AUTHORITY TO SUBPOENA RECORDS AND WITNESSES, AND TO
   20  CONDUCT INTERVIEWS WITH ANY PERSON NECESSARY TO CARRY  OUT  ITS  RIGHTS,
   21  POWERS AND DUTIES PURSUANT TO THIS ARTICLE, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO
   22  STAFF AND CHILDREN UNDER CARE OF THE JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM.
   23    S  538. DUTY TO MAINTAIN CONFIDENTIALITY. ALL RECORDS OF THE INDEPEND-
   24  ENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE PERTAINING TO THE  FULFILLMENT  OF  THE
   25  CHILD ADVOCATE'S RIGHTS, POWERS AND DUTIES PURSUANT TO THIS ARTICLE, AND
   26  ALL  RECORDS  OBTAINED BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL BE KEPT CONFIDENTIAL,
   27  PROVIDED HOWEVER, THAT LIMITED INFORMATION CONTAINED IN SUCH RECORDS MAY
   28  BE RELEASED BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE, IF APPROPRIATE, AND UPON APPROVAL  OF
   29  THE  CHILD ADVOCATE, SO LONG AS THE INFORMATION TO BE RELEASED WOULD NOT
   30  IDENTIFY THE CHILD OR CHILDREN THE CHILD ADVOCATE  WAS  SERVING  OR  THE
   31  NAMES OF THE PARENTS OR SIBLINGS OF SUCH CHILD OR CHILDREN.
   32    S  539.  ADDITIONAL  PROVISIONS.  1.  THE STATE SHALL PROTECT AND HOLD
   33  HARMLESS ANY PERSON EMPLOYED OR APPOINTED BY THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE,  FROM
   34  FINANCIAL  LOSS  AND  EXPENSE,  INCLUDING  LEGAL FEES AND COSTS, IF ANY,
   35  ARISING OUT OF ANY CLAIM, DEMAND OR SUIT FOR DAMAGES RESULTING FROM ACTS
   36  OR OMISSIONS COMMITTED IN THE DISCHARGE OF HIS OR HER RIGHTS, POWERS AND
   37  DUTIES WITHIN THE SCOPE OF HIS OR HER EMPLOYMENT  OR  APPOINTMENT  WHICH
   38  MAY  CONSTITUTE  NEGLIGENCE  BUT WHICH ACTS ARE NOT WANTON, MALICIOUS OR
   39  GROSSLY NEGLIGENT AS DETERMINED BY A COURT OF COMPETENT JURISDICTION.
   40    2. NO STATE OR LOCAL  AGENCY,  DEPARTMENT,  OFFICE,  OR  ENTITY  SHALL
   41  DISCHARGE,  OR  IN  ANY  MANNER  DISCRIMINATE  OR RETALIATE AGAINST, ANY
   42  PERSON WHO IN GOOD FAITH MAKES A COMPLAINT TO, OR COOPERATES  WITH,  THE
   43  CHILD  ADVOCATE  IN  A REVIEW OR EVALUATION CONDUCTED BY THE CHILD ADVO-
   44  CATE. NO EMPLOYEE OF ANY STATE OR LOCAL DEPARTMENT OR OFFICE OR  OF  ANY
   45  PRIVATE  ENTITY SHALL RETALIATE AGAINST ANY PERSON WHO MAKES A COMPLAINT
   46  TO, OR WHO COOPERATES WITH THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD  ADVOCATE
   47  IN  A  REVIEW,  INVESTIGATION OR EVALUATION CONDUCTED BY THE INDEPENDENT
   48  OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   49    3. ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD  ADVOCATE
   50  SHALL  REMAIN  CONFIDENTIAL.  ANY  COMPLAINT FILED BY A YOUTH OR A STAFF
   51  MEMBER OF A JUVENILE JUSTICE FACILITY WITH THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE
   52  CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL REMAIN CONFIDENTIAL. ALL YOUTH RESIDING IN A  JUVE-
   53  NILE  JUSTICE  FACILITY  SHALL BE PERMITTED REASONABLE ACCESS TO A TELE-
   54  PHONE TO MAKE A TOLL FREE CALL OR SHALL BE SUPPLIED WRITING MATERIALS IN
   55  ORDER TO WRITE LETTERS TO THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE
   56  UPON  THE YOUTH'S REQUEST. ANY COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN SUCH YOUTH AND THE

       A. 644                              5

    1  INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL REMAIN  CONFIDENTIAL  AND
    2  SHALL  NOT BE MONITORED BY ANY MEMBER OF THE JUVENILE JUSTICE FACILITY'S
    3  STAFF.
    4    4.  THE  INDEPENDENT  OFFICE  OF  THE CHILD ADVOCATE MAY APPLY FOR AND
    5  ACCEPT GRANTS, GIFTS AND BEQUESTS OF FUNDS FROM PRIVATE INDIVIDUALS  AND
    6  FOUNDATIONS  FOR THE PURPOSE OF CARRYING OUT STUDIES UNDER THIS ARTICLE.
    7  THE FUNDS SHALL BE EXPENDED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE  PROVISIONS  OF  SUCH
    8  GRANT, GIFT OR BEQUEST.
    9    5.  THE  CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL TAKE ALL POSSIBLE ACTIONS INCLUDING, BUT
   10  NOT LIMITED TO, CONDUCTING PROGRAMS  OF  PUBLIC  EDUCATION,  UNDERTAKING
   11  LEGISLATIVE  ADVOCACY AND MAKING PROPOSALS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE CORRECTION
   12  OR REFORM AND FORMAL LEGAL ACTION, IN ORDER TO  SECURE  AND  ENSURE  THE
   13  LEGAL, CIVIL AND SPECIAL RIGHTS OF CHILDREN.
   14    6.  THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE  SHALL TAKE THE APPROPRIATE STEPS TO MAKE THE
   15  EXISTENCE AND AVAILABILITY OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE WIDELY KNOWN, BY APPRO-
   16  PRIATE AND ACTIVE MEANS, TO CHILDREN AND ADULTS.
   17    7. THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL CREATE INFORMATIONAL MATERIALS  FOR  CHIL-
   18  DREN  REGARDING  THE  RIGHTS  OF  CHILDREN  WHEN  THEY  ARE IN DETENTION
   19  CENTERS, FACILITIES OPERATED  BY  THE  OFFICE  OF  CHILDREN  AND  FAMILY
   20  SERVICES,  JAILS, OR PRISONS AND THE METHODS AND ASSISTANCE AVAILABLE TO
   21  ENFORCE THOSE RIGHTS.
   22    S 3. Subdivision 16 of section 501 of the executive law, as renumbered
   23  by chapter 170 of the laws of 1994, is renumbered subdivision 17  and  a
   24  new subdivision 16 is added to read as follows:
   25    16.  THE  COMMISSIONER  OF  THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES
   26  SHALL PROMULGATE REGULATIONS REQUIRING  THAT  NO  SERVICES,  FACILITIES,
   27  ENTITIES  OR  PROGRAMS  UNDER THE JURISDICTION OF THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN
   28  AND FAMILY SERVICES SHALL RESTRICT OR  PROHIBIT  ACCESS  TO  FACILITIES,
   29  RECORDS  OR  INDIVIDUALS TO THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE
   30  UPON REQUEST, UNLESS  THE  DISCLOSURE  OF  SUCH  RECORDS  ARE  OTHERWISE
   31  PROHIBITED BY FEDERAL LAW OR REGULATION.
   32    S 4. This act shall take effect April 1, 2012; provided, however, that
   33  effective immediately, the addition, amendment and/or repeal of any rule
   34  or regulation necessary for the implementation of this act on its effec-
   35  tive  date  are  authorized  and directed to be made and completed on or
   36  before the effective date.
